values:
Any of you see the diamond ad where the guy starts screaming in the middle of the crowded plaza "I love this woman!  I love her!"?  I feel like that almost every day, but especially today.  It's our 2 year anniversary!  I really wish I could have been with her today, but I had work...and a really bad cold.  Seriously, I looked like death warmed over this morning.

I can't believe we've been together two years.  It's been quite a rollercoaster ride the past two years, but I can't think of anyone I'd rather ride that rollercoaster with than Em.  I've never felt so happy, so content, so utterly perfect and safe and warm than when I do with her.

Here's to two of the happiest years of my life...and looking forward to many, many more!

It's time to be honest with myself on certain things, like eating.  I've made two observations about my "natural" eating habits a lot in the past month:

1. When I eat alone, I overeat.  I eat relatively well when I'm with my family, or with Em, or my coworkers, or anybody...but when I'm by myself I find myself in the drive-thru at McDonald's or with my face buried in another bowl of ice cream or chips.

2. Speaking of the drive-thru, I eat out way too much.  I would have so much more money at the end of the day if I didn't eat out, money that could be spent on paying off my credit card, or my line of credit, or buying flowers for my sweetheart, or on a hobby (and playing poker at the Bruder's is not a hobby).

I've been plotting for the last week where to make changes in these eating habits, what would challenge me to eat better and lose weight and what was still practical.  After much thought, this is what I've decided:

1. I am not allowed to eat alone.  Other people don't necessarily have to eat with me, but I'm not allowed to be eating while I'm by myself.  Breakfast can be at home with family or at the office on "Bagel Wednesday".  Lunch can be with classmates in the MU or with coworkers.  Dinner should be at home, but occassionally with volunteers (although any of these with my sweetheart would be preferred over anything else!)

2. I am not allowed to eat at any restaurant that has a drive-thru window.  Period.  No questions asked.  Just because we have choir socials at Dairy Queen doesn't mean I have to get the chocolate chip cookie dough blizzard.

3. I am allowed to have breakfast, lunch, and dinner out one time per week.  This seems like a lot for most people, but for me it's cutting way back.  As much as I enjoy cooking Em and I always end up going out (assuming we remember to eat!).  And I enjoy eating out with Em, or with my family, or with my coworkers, and this way I don't have to give up IHOP with Em (at least till I get you one of the plants) or anchovy pizza with Deacon Gene.  Good conversation makes the food taste better anyway.

As for what food is acceptable:

Breakfast should be cereal or oatmeal with a piece of fruit.  If mom's making something special like eggs or biscuits, I'm going to eat it, but the donuts and danish are off-limits at breakfast.

Morning snack should be a piece of fruit, if I'm hungry.  Otherwise, just a cup of coffee.

Lunch should be a sandwich (meat and cheese on whole wheat bread, no mayo) or a salad (with low-fat or fat free dressing) and water or diet soda.

Afternoon snack should be a Zone Bar (210-220 calories -- seems like a lot, but some nights I don't get dinner till 830 or 9 at night).

Dinner is whatever the family is cooking (or has cooked already), keeping to lean meats or fish, a starch, and a vegetable as our normal meal, with water or diet soda to drink.

Dessert is acceptable, as long as I'm eating with someone else!  This is one meal where someone must be eating with me, not just be with me.

My exercise plan:

Any day that I work, I must work out for at least a half hour.  I will either start working out more or start working less, either of which would be beneficial to my overall cardiovascular health.

Wow this is a long post for me!  But I needed to say it.  I know that those of you reading this (especially you, Em) will keep my honest with myself on my progress!

Today was a very nice mix of prayerfulness and silliness.  Mass was beautiful this morning.  It was the first time I've ever been anointed at a healing Mass, and it felt very powerful, very moving.  It gave me the strength to reflect on some areas of my life where I don't take my faith as seriously as I should, and some things to talk about with my confessor tomorrow.  Stations this evening was very prayerful too.  I love the devotion of Stations of the Cross, and even though I sometimes am tired of the repetitiveness of the stations we use at All Saints, there's something about the reflections that always speaks to me.

My daily funny: So before stations, this man stops me.  "Hey, tony (all the old people call me tony, I don't get it), I got a question for ya.  I'm 73, do I still have to fast?"  I told him that he didn't, but he still needed to abstain from meat on Fridays of Lent.  The man replied, "I knew it!  My wife will do anything to get outta cooking dinner!"

Okay, back to being reflective...

Lately I've been overworking big time...I won't say how big, but very big.  I've let my grades suffer (B's, and I know I can do better in these classes), I've let my prayer life suffer, and I've let my relationships with the people I love suffer because I pour myself into my work instead of into what really matters in life.  Now that I think about it, I think I've written this journal message before...sometimes it takes multiple attempts to learn a lesson.  I read Em's Xanga where she was talking about the Carrie Underwood song "Jesus Take the Wheel," and how she needs it in her life right now with medical school.  Seeing that really made me pause and say, "Yes...that's it...I'm not the driver here...YOU are!"  I'm trying to control the situations in my life, and I have no control over them..."Grant that I may love you always, and then do with me as you will" from stations tonight.  My first responsibility is not to DO, but to LOVE, and to show that love to my girlfriend, my family, my God, my friends, and to everyone I encounter in life.  Only then can I do, not my will, but His.

Countdown to see Em again: 7 days too many!  But I can't visit now while she's studying for midterms.  Although I'd encourage her to check her mail sometime around 12 noon tomorrow ;-)

Now, to paraphrase the words of Blessed Pope John XXVIII:  "It's your church, [your world, my life in your hands,] Lord.  I'm going to bed."

Just kidding!

I think I should give up church for Lent after the afternoon I had!  Nothing was ready.  NOTHING!  the decorations were all over the place, the handouts weren't put together, the bulletins weren't run!  At least one part was kinda funny...our maintenance crew threw out the dead tree branches a parishioner cut for us to help decorate the baptismal pool.  We needed something to take its place...so...Father and I get into the golf cart, grab a lopper and start scouring the parish grounds for any low branches.  At one point we couldn't reach where we wanted to saw (because we men always assume we're taller than we are) so I reached up, grabbed the end of the branch and ripped it off the tree!  (It's the confidence that new buddy icon gives me!)

Oh...and at one point tonight I compared "Alleluia" to a Cheeseburger!  But, my laundry's done...anyone who wants to hear that story will have to call me. ;-)

Follow the link, and tell me what you see!

Follow the link, and tell me what you see!

so i updated my journal with my most current picture.  look how muscular i have become!  and that i have become black!

Well, this is my last break before the Christmas Masses begin.  I'll be at church from 3pm this afternoon until 2pm tomorrow afternoon, with a break to sleep 4 hours and open presents with the familia.  I'm looking forward to Christmas this year more than last year.  Last year I don't think anyone in the family looked forward to Christmas, right after grandma passed away.  It just wasn't the same.

I miss Em.  It was good to see her earlier this week, but I miss her so much right now!

I hope all of you have a Blessed and Joyous Christmas Season.

From the little brother...I couldn't get the code in right so it's plain text...sorry!


Your brain: 100% interpersonal, 80% visual, 60% verbal, and 160% mathematical!
 
Congratulations on being 400% smart! Actually, on my test, everyone is. The above score breaks down what kind of thinking you most enjoy doing. A score above 100% means you use that kind of thinking more than average, and a score below 100% means you use it less. It says nothing about how good you are at any one, just how interested you are in each, relatively. A substantial difference in scores between two people means, conclusively, that they are different kinds of thinkers. 

Matching Summary: Each of us has different tastes. Still, I offer the following advice, which I think is obvious:


Don't date someone if your interpersonal percentages differ by more than 80%. 
Don't be friends with someone if your verbal percentages differ by more than 100%. 
Don't have sex with someone if their math percentage is over 200%.


My test tracked 4 variables How you compared to other people your age and gender:
  
 You scored higher than 65% on interpersonal 
  
 You scored higher than 30% on visual 
  
 You scored higher than 36% on verbal 
  
 You scored higher than 69% on mathematical 
 

If you liked my test, send it to your friends! 
The 4-Variable IQ Test
http://www.okcupid.com/tests/take?testid=15273633770079357960 


And by the way...I'm going with my church-y icon...you like?

I rarely get into political discussions, but this one (thanks Sean) was too good to pass up!  This poem actually appeared in English in a textbook in Pakistan.  Pay attention to the first letter of each line and what it spells!

THE LEADER by anonymous 

Patient and steady with all he must bear, 
Ready to meet every challenge with care, 
Easy in manner, yet solid as steel, 
Strong in his faith, refreshingly real.
Isn't afraid to propose what is bold, 
Doesn't conform to the usual mould, 
Eyes that have foresight, for hindsight won't do, 
Never backs down when he sees what is true, 
Tells it all straight, and means it all too. 
Going forward and knowing he's right, 
Even when doubted for why he would fight, 
Over and over he makes his case clear, 
Reaching to touch the ones who won't hear. 
Growing in strength he won't be unnerved, 
Ever assuring he'll stand by his word. 
Wanting the world to join his firm stand, 
Bracing for war, but praying for peace,
Using his power so evil will cease,
So much a leader and worthy of trust,
Here stands a man who will do what he must.

When I started dating Em, I warned her to never dare a Casey.  Well...I think I can add on to that "never dare a Schaaf."  That last post was 100% hers, and I dared her to do it, I even gave her the password to do it, in the hopes that I would start posting again.

Well...Here I am!

(And I've used "well..." far too many times in this post already.  Odd.  Very Odd.)

I miss Em so much right now.  I know she has a LOT of studying to do so I'm trying to resist the urge to call her every five minutes.  I'm happy that I get to call her every morning, even if it's just for two minutes.  But it's soooo hard being two hours away.  If I don't see my sweetheart soon I may be committed to the funny farm!  (which is not the same as a laugh factory).

I think I'll bury myself in work this week.  I have to arrange all of our music for Christmas for 5 violins, 1 cello, 1 double bass, 2 flutes, 2 clarinets, 1 bass clarinet, 1 alto sax, 1 tenor sax, 1 trumpet, 2 acoustic guitars, 1 electric guitar, 1 electric bass, drumset, and tympani.  I foresee many an early morning in front of my computer writing in finale before Sunday's music pass-out.

Speaking of work, three priests from the east valley have been in the news in the past week.  Thankfully, the one from our parish is in the news for all the RIGHT reasons.  Fr. Mitchell received the Presidential Volunteer Service Medal on Monday from President Bush during his visit to Phoenix.  Fr. Mitchell has volunteered with at-risk teens and young adults at the Canyon State Acadamy and Project ChalleNGe for over 20 years.  Way to go Fr. Mitchell!

The other two priests' goings-on don't deserve my precious posting time.  'Nuff said.

Ok, that's enough for tonight...more to come later!

Since my *beautiful* girlfriend asked me to start updating my journal, here we go... we'll start with a survey:


*Name:  Tony B.P.C.


*Write 6 facts about yourself as a child:
1.  In 4th grade, we used to have farting contests.  I would always win, as my farting to the tune of America the Beautiful was unbeatable.
2.  When I was in 8th grade, I wanted the be the white power ranger.  His mega-zord was by far the best.
3.  Once someone dared me to eat one of Sandy's dog biscuits.  You know, they really aren't too bad.  Liver has a pretty good flavor... after that, the house was usually short on dog biscuits.
4.  Every year until 11th grade I stayed up late on Christmas Eve waiting for Santa.  I just must not have stayed up late enough, because I could never catch him.  Sneaky old man.
5.  In 10th grade, after school my friends and I would meet at 4pm on the dot to act out Xena:  Warrior Princess.  I never missed a day.
6.  When I was 11, I had strawberry shortcake on my sheets, and I used to pretend she was my girlfriend.  Gosh if only Emily would get that floppy hat of hers...


*Write 6 little known facts about yourself now:
1.  I am tone deaf.  This could be a bad thing if it got out...
2.  When I can't sleep sometimes, I turn on the home shopping network.  There is something so soothing about watching them display those Diamondique bracelets.
3.  I dream of one day owning a ferret.
4.  Speaking of sleeping, I feel most comfortable sleeping in my He-Man, Master of the Universe footie pajamas.
5.  I have a huge phobia of flying insects.  Those ladybugs are so aggressive sometimes.
6.  I plan on naming my first son Bruce.  


Speaking of Bruce...


Second Bruce: G'day, Bruce! 

First Bruce: Oh, Hello Bruce!

Third Bruce: How are you Bruce?

First Bruce: A bit crook, Bruce.

Second Bruce: Where's Bruce?

First Bruce: He's not 'ere, Bruce.

Third Bruce: Blimey, it's hot in here, Bruce.

First Bruce: Hot enough to boil a monkey's bum!

Second Bruce: That's a strange expression, Bruce.

First Bruce: Well Bruce, I heard the Prime Minister use it. "It's hot enough to boil a monkey's bum in here, your Majesty," he said and she smiled quietly to herself.

Third Bruce: She's a good Sheila Bruce, and not at all stuck up.

Second Bruce: Here! Here's the boss-fellow now! - how are you bruce?

(Enter fourth Bruce with English person, Michael)

Fourth Bruce: 'Ow are you, Bruce?

First Bruce: G'day Bruce!

Fourth Bruce: Bruce.

Second Bruce: Hello Bruce.

Fourth Bruce: Bruce.

Third Bruce: How are you, Bruce?

Fourth Bruce: G'day Bruce.

Fourth Bruce: Gentleman, I'd like to introduce man from Pommeyland who is joinin' us this year in the philosophy department at the University of Walamaloo.

Everybruce: G'day!

Michael: Hello.

Fourth Bruce: Michael Baldwin, Bruce. Michael Baldwin, Bruce. Michael Baldwin, Bruce.

First Bruce: Is your name not Bruce?

Michael: No, it's Michael.

Second Bruce: That's going to cause a little confusion.

Third Bruce: Mind if we call you "Bruce" to keep it clear?

Fourth Bruce: Gentlemen, I think we better start the faculty meeting. Before we start, though, I'd like to ask the padre for a prayer.

First Bruce: Oh Lord, we beseech Thee, Amen!!

Everybruce: Amen!

Fourth Bruce: Crack tubes! (Sound of cans opening) Now I call upon Bruce to officially welcome Mr. Baldwin to the philosophy faculty.

Second Bruce: I'd like to welcome the pommey bastard to God's own Earth, and remind him that we don't like stuck-up sticky-beaks here.

Everybruce: Hear, hear! Well spoken, Bruce!

Fourth Bruce: Bruce here teaches classical philosophy, Bruce there teaches Haegelian philosophy, and Bruce here teaches logical positivism. And is also in charge of the sheep dip.

Third Bruce: What's New-Bruce going to teach?

Fourth Bruce: New-Bruce will be teaching political science, Machiavelli, Bentham, Locke, Hobbes, Sutcliffe, Bradman, Lindwall, Miller, Hassett, and Benaud.

Second Bruce: Those are all cricketers!

Fourth Bruce: Aww, spit!

Third Bruce: Hails of derisive laughter, Bruce!

Everybruce: Australia, Australia, Australia, Australia, we love you amen!

Fourth Bruce:Bruce: Crack tube! (Sound of cans opening) Any questions?

Second Bruce: New-Bruce, are you a Poofter?

Fourth Bruce: Are you a Poofter?

Michael: No!

Fourth Bruce: No. Right, I just want to remind you of the faculty rules: Rule One! 

Everybruce: No Poofters!

Fourth Bruce: Rule Two, no member of the faculty is to maltreat the Abbos in any way at all -- if there's anybody watching. Rule Three? 

Everybruce: No Poofters!!

Fourth Bruce: Rule Four, now this term, I don't want to catch anybody not drinking. Rule Five, 

Everybruce: No Poofters!

Fourth Bruce: Rule Six, there is NO ... Rule Six. Rule Seven, 

Everybruce: No Poofters!!

Fourth Bruce: Right, that concludes the readin' of the rules, Bruce.

First Bruce: This here's the wattle, the emblem of our land. You can stick it in a bottle, you can hold it in your hand.

Everybruce: Amen!

(NB: The Album versions continue with the Philosopher's song The TV version continues below....) 

First Bruce: Right, let's get some Sheilas. 

(An Aborigine bunts in with an enormous tray full of enormous steaks.) 

Fourth Bruce: OK. 

Second Bruce: Ah, elevenses. 

Third Bruce: This should tide us over 'til lunchtime. 

Second Bruce: Reckon so, Bruce. 

First Bruce: Sydney Nolan! What's that! (points) 

(Cut to dramatic close-up of Fourth Bruce's ear. Hold close-up. The superimposed arrow pointing to the ear.) 

Voice Over: Number nine. The ear. 

*****Album Version Continued****** 

(And now all four Bruces launch into the Philosopher's song) 

Immanuel Kant was a real piss-ant who was very rarely stable.
Heideggar, Heideggar was a boozy beggar who could think you under the table.
David Hume could out-consume Wilhelm Freidrich Hegel.
And Whittgenstein was a beery swine who was just as sloshed as Schlegel.
There's nothing Nieizsche couldn't teach 'ya 'bout the raising of the wrist.
Socrates, himself, was permanently pissed.
John Stewart Mill, of his own free will, after half a pint of shanty was particularly ill.
Plato, they say, could stick it away, half a crate of whiskey every day!
Aristotle, Aristotle was a bugger for the bottle,
And Hobbes was fond of his Dram.
And Rene Descartes was a drunken fart:
"I drink, therefore I am."
Yes, Socrates himself is particularly missed;
A lovely little thinker, but a bugger when he's pissed.

Well, I don't post much in here, and I need a good place to keep a log of what I'm doing towards losing weight...so I think I'll start putting it here.  I know...it's not very interesting...in fact, it sounds pretty boring....but I gotta do it!

I'm using the dietary guidelines for the "new food pyramid" http://www.mypyramid.gov <-- don't go to .org or else you'll get a fake site!  For a 22 year old "sedentary" male, my goals are:

Calories: 2400
Grains: 8 oz
Vegetables: 3 cups
Fruits: 2 cups
Milk/Dairy: 3 cups
Meat: 6.5 ounces
Total Fat: 30% or less
Sat Fat: 10% or less
Cholesterol: 300 mg or less
Sodium: 1800-2300 mg

Future posts will tell you what I ate...and how I did.  I know all my buddies out there have dealt with wanting to lose weight at one point or another...so I will take any pointers or advice you want to give!

How do I summarize the last two months without posting?   In the words of a great priest I know: "I am blessed."

I am blessed to have life in a world where so many lives are taken through acts of violence or hate.

I am blessed to be a Catholic in a world that is afraid to always believe in God.

I am blessed to have parents who love me in a world where so many children are abandoned.

I am blessed to have a girlfriend who loves me from the heart in a world where people are afraid to love.

I am blessed to have old friends who struggle to keep in touch in a world where time seems to pass without a second's thought.

I am blessed to have new friends in a world where people are afraid to reach out to each other.

I am blessed to have food in a world where so many people starve.

I am blessed to have a job in a world where so many are unemployed.

I am blessed to have a job that makes a difference to others in a world where so many must settle for unsatisfying work for unsatisfying pay.

I am blessed to have the intelligence to go to school in a world where intelligence is neglected for the easy fix.

I am blessed to have a car that runs in a world where some people never leave home in their entire lives.

I am blessed to know that the most important things in life are at the top of this list, not the bottom!

1. Get in Shape: Go to the gym daily (excluding Sundays)

I have a workout plan!  YAY!!!!

Cardio: alternate treadmill and bike (currently at 25 min, 130bpm HR)
Abs: every other day, 3x8 on super-crunch machine (uses body weight plus adds additional; trust me you FEEL it!!!)
Upper body weights: Mon,Wed,Fri...3x10 sets...30-70lbs depending on body part
Lower body weights: Tue,Thu,Sat...3x10 sets...70-100lbs depending body part

2. Prayer Life: Pray liturgy of the Hours daily

I give myself an F minus on this one.   BUT Emily and I have been praying together every night before we go to bed for the last week and a half.  It's not my original goal, but it's an increase in my prayer life!

3. Mental Health: Take at least one day off a week from work

ummm...1 outta 3...gotta improve that record!

4. Academic: All A's...we can do it!

So far, so good!!!

EMILY I MISS YOU SOOOOO MUCH!!

So I decided to stop at Denny's for lunch this morning after class.  I never eat at Denny's.  I really don't care for the restaurant, but for some reason, I wanted to eat there.  I order my cup of coffee and something off the breakfast menu, and wait.  As the waitress comes over to bring my food, she asks me if I remember the man sitting at the booth next to me.  I told her yes, so she replied, "he paid for your meal, he says it's an early Christmas present."  I don't know what I did to deserve it (maybe I rushed out of the house this morning and looked like I was broke), but that was so nice of him!

My sweetheart was accepted to Loyola Medical School!!!

I'm so happy for her!

courtesy of www.pressanykey.com:

Anthony

The name of Anthony gives you a clever, quick, analytical mind, but you suffer with a great deal of self-consciousness, lack of confidence, and much aloneness because of misunderstandings. Your idealistic and sensitive nature gives you a deep appreciation for the finer things of life and a strong desire to be of service to humanity. There are times when you experience inner turbulence at your inability to say what you mean. It is far easier for you to express your deeper thoughts and feelings through writing than verbally. You find pleasure in literature, in poetry, and in your ideals and will turn to them when you feel you have been misunderstood. You are deeply moved by the beauties of life, especially nature. Because your feelings run deep, you must guard against the ups and downs, being very inspired one minute, then moody, reserved, and depressed the next. Your reactions to people vary according to how you feel. You tend to be secretive and noncommittal about private matters, yet at times you will talk effusively in order to hide your self-consciousness or to lead others away from personal subjects. You are inspired by encouragement from others, yet suspicious of their intent. You crave affection but seldom find anyone who understands your nature. Physical weaknesses would show in your heart, lungs, or bronchial organs.

My pre-registration request for Spring 2005:

I received a phone call at 3:30 this afternoon that the bishop will be celebrating Mass at our parish on All Saints day, november 1st!  How exciting!

Now, as the assistant liturgist, it's my job to read the "Ceremonial of Bishops" and prepare a listing of everything we need to do by Monday morning when my boss returns.  Already I need to figure out where I'm gonna find about a dozen altar servers...

passed away early Friday morning.  I know it seems like it's taken me a long time to write after this, but I have been writing, just not for people to see right now.  I've talked about everything with some of you, others not as much.  Sorry for not writing, it just that some thoughts can only be shared with certain people, and best not shared as journal entries.

I had a wonderful weekend!  It was very good to see Emily Friday night :-)  Maybe a little too much fun, I only had about 2 and a half hours of sleep!  I came back much earlier than I wanted to the next morning because I had to sing for a wedding, but it was a very nice wedding.  I knew the bride and groom from their involvement at the parish, which always makes it nicer for me to sing (it's more than just a paycheck).  After that, meetings with Youth Ministry, fixing the sound system in the church, early dinner, and an early bedtime.

Sunday was Mass (of course!), homework, and laundry.  Simple yet rewarding.  Mom and Dad rearranged the kitchen while I was gone to give dad more counterspace.  he starts Culinary school tomorrow, how exciting for him!  Okay, enough rambling from me!

Father's homily at Mass this morning was quite good.  He talked about our need for patience and perseverance in the Lord, and that what we ask for from the Lord happens in His time, not our own.  There's so much I want to happen right now.  I want to be done with my schooling and move on with my life.  I want to be with Emily, I miss her so much.  I want the choirs to realize their full potential and be the best choirs this parish has ever seen.  But all of that takes time, and the timetable is in God's hands, not mine.

At the same time, Father pointed out that while trusting in God, we must serve as instruments of God's plan.  "If you had faith but the size of a mustard seed..."  My faith must transform myself and the lives of those around me through prayer and action.  Instead of wishing for school to be over, I can give my 100% best focus whenever I have to chance to for my schooling.  I pray for Emily, for her success and happiness and that we can be together soon, and hopefully show her every time I can how important she is to me.  I know the choirs can only reach their full potential if I, as their director, bring out the talents they hold inside of them and nourish them with prayer and practice.

For the first time in a while, I think I'm doing better on my schoolwork than my work work.  My classes are all going really well this semester...it's a really good feeling to be doing this well.  On the other hand...I can't seem to get caught up at work.  So many things are being thrown at me these last few weeks that I haven't really had time to catch up.  I'll spend a good two hours in the office when I get there just trying to clear my desk so I can do the work I really need to do that day.  And this is supposed to be our "light" time of year for work and projects.

I do get a night off tonight though.  I'll work extra hard tomorrow before heading down to Tucson to visit Emily this weekend :-)  Then it's meetings, meetings, and more meetings!

The good (and not so good) of the weekend:

Not so good (I mean, come on, let's get this part over with!):
- ethics readings that really tick me off.  To say that "unborn babies aren't real persons, just like the mentally handicapped" really annoys me.  Actually ... to say that I was annoyed would be like calling having your head chopped off a paper cut.
- RUDE parents.  we had confirmation orientation this afternoon.  One parent pulled his son out of the class because her degree is in religious studies, making her "incompetent" to teach Catholicism.  I dunno buddy, but if two priests with theology degrees think she's ok, I'm gonna trust them.

Good stuff:
+ 12pm choir was on fire today.  7 singers, piano, 2 guitar, bass, drumset, congas, & flute.  The congregation was larger and more responsive, and the choir's getting into it more too.  I think having the sound pro come and fix the system was a huge help, we could actually hear each other in the choir area.
+ a 95% average on my species counterpoint homework.  Of course, all species counterpoint is is following rules, and that's about how often I follow the rules with everything else, so it's par for the course.
+ E-cards from very special people who always now how to make me "light up" :-)

Next week:  easy week for school...lots of meetings at work.  Wedding saturday to sing for (couple converted last year, so they know me through the OCI program -- always more fun to sing for people you know!)

Today was very relaxing for me.  It was the first day I haven't been in to work in almost two weeks...a very welcome break!  I went to get my haircut and went up to JCPenney to buy some jeans.  This afternoon I helped dad rearrange furniture in the bedrooms...so I guess that wasn't that lazy, but oh well.  It still beats homework...

...which I will have to do tomorrow.  I have a sightsinging exam on Tuesday and a Philosophy midterm on Wednesday, so I'll be having lots of fun!

The little kids sing tomorrow for the first time.  I'm excited and nervous for them.  I know they'll be just great!

...and I can't stop thinking about Emily...I knew I should've followed my gut and went down there today... :-)

The sheer stupidity of some of my peers at the univeristy is truly amazing.  I can't honestly believe that these people have lasted this long in college.  I'm taking an upper division applied ethics course...our first test was last week.  Today our professor called eight people out of the room and kicked them all out for the semester for cheating.

First off...cheating is stupid.  Second off...cheating off of your significant other is stupid.  Third off...of all the classes where you could possibly cheat, you choose ETHICS?

Children's choir was ok tonight...the kids need to strengthen themselves vocally.  My boss decided that we would use organ with the kids this weekend (which I'm not happy about...they have trouble with just piano accompaniment, and now they're supposed to have both piano and organ?  I'm not very happy about this.  Oh well.

I had a perfect score on my melodic dictation test even without the bonus dictation.  One theory test down for the week, one to go!

I hate it when non-philosophy classes try to have deep philosophical conversations.  My interdisciplinary studies class today had a discussion on university education and needs for reform within the system.  Our professor prepared notes for us on Hellenist understandings of education and knowledge, the founding of the first universities, the truvium and quadrivium, unity of the disciplines, fragmentation of the disciplines and its causes, etc.  Instead of focusing our discussion on real issues about what is knowledge and what should an education provide...all the class wanted to discuss was petty little things like the cost of books and parking.  :-P  Very Frustrating!

I got to see my cousin's newborn baby boy today!  He's so cute!  Now if only I can remember the kid's name...I think species counterpoint in music theory has fried my brain cells.

and because I like Emily lots...  ;-)

I'll start posting again!

I went to the music composition studio recital last night.  There were some...umm...interesting pieces.  Some highlights:

-- I didn't know that japanese karaoke music forms were studied at ASU!
-- I didn't know that augmented and diminished chords were supposed to create a "pastoral" feel of an April afternoon
-- I didn't know fortune cookies, playground taunting, and warning labels made for really good song lyrics.

I had a 97% on my first ethics test -- I guess it's because I'm such an ethical person.  I think I aced my melodic dictation test for theory -- I should find out on Thursday.

Choir practice was great tonight...except that my conga stand was broken, so I had to stick the drum between my legs to play it, but it worked.  This Sunday is a special Mass for all the RE and YM teachers at the 12pm, so we're tying in music realating to the readings on stewardship to our call to service to others.  It will be wonderful!

Agenda for the week...Papers due tomorrow and thursday...theory test friday...server training tomorrow...children's choir thursday...this weekend?  who knows -- I'm open to suggestions.
